But here's one thing you can try in the meantime: when the "this is temporary" thought shows up, instead of fighting it or trying to convince yourself everything will be fine forever, just acknowledge it and add a second truth next to it. Something like: "Yeah, things could change. And also, right now, today, things are actually good." Both can be true. You don't have to eliminate the uncertainty to let yourself experience the present moment.

Another angle: ask yourself what the "waiting for the bottom to drop out" thought is trying to do for you. Is it trying to protect you from disappointment by pre-ruining the good thing? Is it keeping you vigilant so you won't be caught off-guard if something bad happens? Sometimes anxiety holds onto these thoughts because it believes they're useful—like bracing for impact will somehow soften the blow. But in reality, all it does is steal the good moments without actually preventing the bad ones. Noticing *what the thought is trying to do* can help you see it as a pattern instead of a truth.
